entry.title: Flight Sim Awards 2025 at FSWeekend Announced
entry.summary: Sim: OTHER. Threshold, cruiselevel, and FSElite are excited to announce the Flight Sim Awards, taking place at FSWeekend 2025! The Flight Sim Awards aim to celebrate the developers, creators, and innovators who make our enjoyment of flight simulation possible. The jury, selected from members of the Threshold, cruiselevel, and FSElite teams have reviewed all product releases from 2024. After careful deliberation, the nominees have been narrowed down to a select few finalists in each category. In MSFS and X-Plane, there are three categories: airliners, aircraft and scenery. Additionally, the best add-on for DCS has its own category, along with the best tools, hardware, and freeware for the entire flight sim genre. To conclude, there is a special Content Creator category where you, along with thousands of other fans, determine the winner! â Members of the jury are not the only ones who have a say in the decision. Starting this Friday, February 14, you can vote for your favourites! The final result will be determined by a 50/50 split between the jury and the public votes. Categories will be scored using a point system. Award five points to your favourite, four points to your second favourite, three points to your third favourite, and so on for your top five. Juries will follow the same scoring system. The entry with the most combined points at the end will be declared the winner! â The flight simulation community has no shortage of great content creators. The Flight Sim Awards aim to recognize your favourites, and this category will truly showcase who your top choice is, as 100 percent of the points are determined by the public. â The 2025 Flight Sim Awards will take place on Friday, March 14, the eve before FSWeekend in Lelystad at the Captain's Dinner. For those who cannot attend the event in person, a live stream will be available. â As we celebrate this yearâs achievements, we also look ahead to the future. The jury is eager to hear your thoughts and feedback to make the 2026 Flight Sim Awards even better! âIf you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Salvuz Releases Bergen Airport for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Salvuz recently released their rendition of Bergen Airport (ENBR) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024. It is the second busiest airport in Norway, with a yearly average of 6 million passengers. Dating back to the early 1950s, Bergen Airport was partially funded by the municipalities of Bergen and Fana with 4 million Norwegian kroner, securing the construction of a terminal and a 1,460-meter-long runway. NATO funded an expansion in 1953, warranting a 2,440-meter-long runway instead. When the first flight landed at the airport in mid-1954, only 800 meters were complete. It was a chartered flight from Bergen to Oslo, transporting a local football team. Itâs a hub for Norwegian Air Shuttle, Scandinavian Airlines, and WiderÃ¸e, with an extensive domestic and intra-European network. According to 2014 data, Scandinavian Airlines had 46% of the market share for domestic flights, Norwegian had 38%, and WiderÃ¸e 15%. Internationally, Norway led the way with 36%, SAS with 23%, and KLM with 18% (with a single route to Amsterdam).Â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with highly detailed buildings, high-resolution PBR textures, custom jetways, an up-to-date layout (as of 2024), and it also supports MSFS 24âs new lighting and LOD system. entry.title: PMDG Publishes Development Update for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. PMDG has recently published a new development update concerning the status of their product lines for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, including further information on the upcoming 777-200ER and the 747 Classic project. The upcoming 777-200ERâs beta testing phase has finally started. The plane will feature all three engine variants (GE, RR, and PW) with their correct performance figures, indications, and sounds.Â â While there is no timeline for the beta testing phase to end, Randazzo suspects they will have a better feel for the qualitative state of the product in the next 7-10 days. â Like the 777F, the 777-200ER will be available for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 first, with a 2024 version to be released later. â PMDG has also announced a new Operations Center (3.0), which is currently under beta testing as well and will eventually replace their current Operations Center, sporting a fresh new look, the ability to manage all product installations from within it, update management, rollbacks, and multiple channels (stable, experimental, beta, streamer builds). It will also handle activation and install rights and significantly improve PMDGâs ability to diagnose and resolve any problems that might occur with their products at hand.Â Furthermore, the new Operations Center will eliminate the need for installers, which used to be one of their biggest choke points during product releases. â Itâs scheduled to roll out soon and coexist with 2.0 until they are wholly comfortable with the new methods. â Regarding the status of the 777âs conversion to Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, PMDG has managed to build its lineup inside the new platform with great success, but some stability issues were found that would ultimately break the experience.Â Despite the slightly underwhelming results, PMDG remains optimistic that their ârelationshipâ with Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 will improve as Asobo updates the platform. â On the other hand, the DCâ6â which they assumed would be an easy conversionâhas proven to be one of the trickiest, with numerous problems with the animations (including cockpit controls, levers, buttons, and other items). They have been unable to determine what is causing the problem so far. â They have reported the issue in Asoboâs dev community forums, but it appears to have not caught their attention yet, and no other developer has encountered anything similar. In light of this, PMDG has provided no ETA for its eventual conversion to the new platform. â 737NG-wise, they have not yet evaluated it in the new platform, as they are using the 777 as a testbed to learn the ropes. As for the upgrade pricing, PMDGâs position remains the same: while they ideally do not want to charge, they might have to charge depending on the amount of work required (they havenât fully gauged how much effort will be necessary yet). â Work on the 747 fleet has been accelerating while everything else remains relatively stagnant due to the compatibility stalemate. Randazzo reiterates that things are still moving, though slowly.Â â While the 747-400 doesnât have any images yet, they have shared two pictures of the flight deck work on the 747-100, showcasing the newly started labeling work, custom weathering, etc.Â Coding is also progressing nicely, with PMDG taking full advantage of the âstalemateâ to move developers on and off the 747. â PMDGâs product lineup is available on their official website, with prices ranging from $34.99 to $74.99 If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: TDS Sim Software Releases GTNXi for X-Plane
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. TDS Sim Software has recently released GTNXi for X-Plane 11 and 12. The GTNXi is a rendition of the Garmin 650Xi and 750Xi navigation with support for both Navigraph charts and data. Like its real-life counterpart, the GTNXi provides the pilot with various features, such as full autopilot control laterally and vertically (including support for LPV approaches), 8.33kHz COM frequency spacing, the ability to fly RF legs, a Glide Range Ring, a Smart Glide, and a Nearest Airport Indication Arrow. It also supports dual GPS/Flight plans, per-device CDI, mouse wheel zoom-in/out of the map page, full VC integration and a 2D pop-up available concurrently, worldwide live METAR, SmartGlide, and much more. The full list is rather lengthy, but it can be found in the .pdf manual included with the addon. The TDS GTNXi comes with VC integration support for X-Plane 12 for the following add-ons: If your favourite general aviation plane isnât on the list, don't worry! The GTNXi comes with Legacy VC Integration, which can detect and install the TDS add-on into all add-on aircraft that provide a legacy GTN 3D bezel unit. According to the developers, this will be useful for users with X-Plane 11 aircraft, as those will not come with TDS GTNXi VC Integration standards. More information about this can also be found in the .pdf manual. If the aircraft doesnât have VC-integrated GPS support, you can always use it as a 2D pop-up. The TDS Sim Softwareâs GTNXi can be purchased here for roughly $ 68.20. It requires X-Plane 11/12, Windows 10 (version 1909) or Windows 11, Intel Core i5-12600K or AMD Ryzen 5 3500, at least 16GB of RAM memory, Nvidia RTX2070 or AMD Radeon RX 5700XT, with at least 4GB of video card memory, and at least 6GB of free space on hard disk. Navigraph subscription is also required for database updates and charts. If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: X-Crafts Releases E-Jets Family Version 2.0 in Open Beta
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. The E-Jets Family for X-Plane, developed by X-Crafts, has just launched version 2.0 in an open beta. The full release is expected in just a few weeks. This update includes a variety of new features, improvements, and fixes, and introduces a rendition of the Embraer Lineage 1000. The latest update is filled with exciting new features. The E-Jets now offer three distinct lighting options: X-Plane default, dynamic, or natural lighting. Please note that these features are only available in X-Plane 12 and not in X-Plane 11. Additionally, users can now simulate the real-life noise-cancelling headsets used by pilots. The Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) has also been updated significantly. Both the fuel and auto brake systems have been completely overhauled. These are just a few highlights of the changes; for the complete list, please refer to the release notes. The current price for the full E-Jets Family is $134.95. It is important to note that once version 2.0 is fully released, the price will increase to $149.95. Additionally, the upgrade price will rise to $74.48. If you choose to purchase or upgrade to the full E-Jets Family before the 2.0 release, you will receive the Lineage 1000 for free. The full release is currently estimated to be on the 1st of March. The E-Jets Family can be found at the X-Plane.Org Software Store.
